title: Don’t Disturb My Circles! Boundary Preservation Is at the Center of Location-Sharing Concerns

author: Xinru Page, University of California, Irvine

segmentation: So while the famous scientist mathematician Archimedes, was busy drawing mathematical diagrams in the sand, invading Roman soldiers came in common by surprise, and his famous last words were don't disturb my circles.
The sentiment still holds today in the world of social media, but rather than geometric circles, people want to preserve the boundaries of their social circles.
In our research, we found that boundary preservation concerns are root cause of many location sharing privacy concerns found throughout the literature.
I'll touch on some of these common privacy concerns before showing how they all trace back to this concept of relational boundary preservation.
We believe this work has implications for the design of local share location sharing systems as well As for social media in general.
So location sharing services allow you to share your location with friends and know where your family is.
Etc.
In recent years many location sharing services have come out on the social media landscape, including Foursquare, Google Attitude, Facebook places and GPS enabled.
Smartphones are also becoming very popular.
Nearly half of US adults now own a smartphone, but among the smartphone users, while 74% have use location based services.
So navigation or something where you use it to get information only 18% have tried geosocial services where you're sharing with other people.
Previous research and a lot of the media attributes this slow adoption to diverse privacy concern.

So, including informational disclosure that kind of thing interactional where you're compelled to interact with somebody psychological you impression management, self presentation, and physical, physical access, that kind of thing.
But there are other hand there.

Lot of counterexamples where privacy doesn't seem to be an issue, so people share a lot of information despite threats to their employment, safety issues, potential embarrassment, and there are even several location sharing services out there that allow you to meet strangers nearby now.

Now these contrasting examples may be explained by conception of privacy, that is, a boundary regulation so privacies an optimal balance between being more open and accessible or being more withdrawn, and you can move that boundary you know back and forth.
Um?
Now, in this conception of privacy, isolation can be a privacy issue as much as over Accessibility.
However, that still doesn't explain what drives people to actually regulate their boundaries.
So our study is to understand these motivations behind that boundary regulation.
We know that people are more open sometimes or more closed, but why?
So.

Because a lot of location studies have been conducted with hypotheticals or researching prototypes with willing volunteers, we began the study by studying publicly available location sharing services used by real people in the World Pass research points to how important is the study non adopters to understand human computer action, and it's just as important as studying actual users and so in the first phase of our study, we conducted semistructured interviews with users LL as well as various types of non adopters.
People who had abandoned or people who.
Explicitly decided not to use and we use an open coding in grounded theory analysis on the data.

Now what this produced was a catalog of the most salient privacy concerns for locations sharing services, other research in location sharing, as well as social media in general has found various concerns, and we found similar ones.
For example, people being bothered by too much information coming in or being compelled to interact, and we've reported on some of these in our.
Our work Now let's say I'm going to talk about a new analysis of that data where we uncovered in May.

We found that people want to preserve their.
Offline relationship boundaries.
And when they use online boundary regulation, so being more open or being more closed, it was a way to preserve the existing boundaries of those relationships.
And so when people are engaging in boundary regulation online, they're actually doing something more specific boundary preservation.

You'll see a bunch of common fit indices on there, and these are standardized coefficients here, and you can see that the boundary preservation concern has a positive effect on all of the individual privacy concerns, and Furthermore social media use has a negative effect on the concern for boundary preservation, and that boundary preservation concern completely mediates the effect on the privacy concerns.

Now, although some of the demographics and controls were significant, significant in one or the other of the samples, none of them were significant in both samples, so we can't make any claims about any of the demographics or controls having an effect.
So I'll summarize some of the key findings from our study.
First of all, you know privacy concerns seem to be a symptom in a way of boundary preservation concerns.
So if you have higher boundary preservation concerns, that will lead to higher privacy concerns and Conversely, if you have lower boundary preservation concerns, you have lower privacy concerns.
Now, focusing on relationship boundaries rather than each of the privacy concerns that can allow us to alleviate some of these symptoms.
So instead of individually going into each privacy concern, say, how do we address this?
This?
I mean, I'm not saying there's no differences between them, but I'm just saying there's we do have a common root that we can address.
The root problem now, for example, Google.
Plus they do a good job for having circles and allowing you to put people into multiple circles so that you can start grouping by relationship.
So that's definitely a step in the right direction.
I think the next step would be to be able to have tools to help us defend those circles, like defend the boundaries of those circles.
So for example, you know not understand the etiquette of using location.
Sharing service was a problem and being concerned about that.
We could provide a way to make it more visible or to shape it somehow, But anyway, I think there's a lot of room for being able to kind of defend those boundaries.
I mean, social networking.

It kind of lacks a lot of the verbal and nonverbal cues and the physical barriers that are in the real world that allow people to defend those boundaries, and so we need to think about how people can establish those boundaries online without those tools or without those cues.
Another key finding was that heavy social media users were less concerned.
About preserving their relationship boundaries and not only that, the effect was completely mediated by the boundary preservation concern, and so this suggests that heavy social media users.
They're not necessarily less privacy concern, but they may just be better at preserving their boundaries, or maybe just less concerned about preserving their boundaries.
So we did see some qualitative support for both of these explanations.

Features or privacy controls.
